<form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkAnswer('module7_mcq_q74')" data-correct-answer="B">
<strong style="display: block;">Under Modigliani and Miller Proposition I (no taxes), which statement correctly describes the effect of changing a firm’s debt ratio on its overall cost of capital?</strong>

<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q74" value="A"> A. Increasing leverage lowers the firm’s weighted average cost of capital (WACC).</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q74" value="B"> B. The WACC remains constant because changes in debt and equity costs exactly offset each other.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q74" value="C"> C. The WACC increases because equity becomes riskier.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q74" value="D"> D. The WACC decreases only if the cost of equity remains constant.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module7_mcq_q74" value="E"> E. The firm’s WACC fluctuates unpredictably with leverage.</label><br>
</form>

<div id="feedback-module7_mcq_q74" class="feedback" data-status="" style="display:none;">
✅ Correct: B. According to MM Proposition I (no taxes), the total value of the firm and its weighted average cost of capital ($r_U$) are invariant to capital structure.  
As leverage increases, $r_E$ rises but this is exactly offset by the cheaper cost of debt, keeping $r_U$ constant.
</div>
